title.narrative: Climate change and indigenious people in developing countries

description.narrative: The theme of the project is the impacts of climate change in developing countries as well as preventing the impacts and adaptation to them. The role of the indiginious people in fighting against climate change is highlighted in the project and the theme is addressed through different cases. The project concentrates especially on the new project of Siemenpuu foundation carried out with the Indigenous Peoples of Africa Coordinating Committee (IPACC). IPACC is an umbrella organisation of indiginious people's N GO's in Africa. In recent years IPACC has been especially active with climate questions. The organisation has produced a manual on approaches for integrating indigenous and traditional knowledge into National Adaptation Plans which will be published in UNF CCC COP20 in Lima in December 2014. At grass-roots level the project of Siemenpuu and IPACC aims to strengthen Kenyan forest-based indigenous peoples? collaboration in developing climate change mitigation safeguards support their advocacy on the theme towa rds the government as well as contribute to including traditional knowledge as part of the National Adaptation Plans.Concretely the project produces a theme volume of e-journal Tuuma (www.visili.fi). Some of the articles are also published in the paper ver sion of the journal published as an attachment of Vihrea Lanka newspaper. Also a high-level seminar will be organised with professional speakers. For instance Secretary General of IPACC will be invited to speak in the seminar. A possibility for distance pa rticipation is provided with streaming the seminar to internet. The speeches of the seminar will be collected into report distributed to all seminar participants. The purpose of the project is to bring new knowledge to target groups on the connection of cl imate and development co-operation questions and indicate that development co-operation can empower local communities to act on behalf of their environment.
